		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/04/28/how-to-make-the-most-of-a-small-kitchen/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2011 18:10:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=128</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Homeowners often note small rooms as one of their biggest challenges, and tiny space is even more of a hardship in the heart of the home. For those of you plagued with small kitchens, we’ve compiled some helpful tips from <a href="http://www.housebeautiful.com/kitchens/small-kitchen-ideas" target="_blank"><em>House Beautiful</em></a>and <a href="http://www.bhg.com/kitchen/small/make-a-small-kitchen-look-larger/" target="_blank"><em>Better Homes and Gardens</em></a> that will not only make the space look larger, but also will make it more practical and functional for use.
<ul>
	<li>Take the cabinets higher to add storage space and a more expansive look.</li>
	<li>Mirrors make any room look larger. Take advantage of this in the kitchen with a mirrored backsplash.</li>
	<li>Use any available natural light. If you have a window, limit the treatments to let the light shine in.</li>
	<li>Knock down part of a wall so the kitchen looks more open.</li>
</ul>
Of course, remodeling is also a great option when it comes to small kitchens. A kitchen renovation could literally make the room larger or a remodel could incorporate the best cabinets and appliances to make the most of the available space. <a href="http://gelottehommas.com/default.html" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> in Bellevue, Washington, would be happy to help you solve your tiny kitchen dilemma, so <a href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/contact-us/" target="_blank">contact us</a> today.

<em>Photo via <a href="http://www.bhg.com/kitchen/small/make-a-small-kitchen-look-larger/" target="_blank">Better Homes and Gardens</a></em>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Accenting Indoor Architecture With Plant-Infused Green Walls</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/08/accenting-indoor-architecture-with-plant-infused-green-walls/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 08 Jun 2011 00:00:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=135</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There’s a new product and trend in architecture that’s positively infatuating: Accenting indoor architecture with plant-infused green walls. These walls are literally walls of plant life to help bring the outdoors in, to infuse more urban spaces with plant life, and to help filter the air indoors.
<div class="mceTemp">

[caption id="attachment_138" align="alignnone" width="600" caption="This plant-lined walk way is colorful, modern, and inviting, with added touches of whimsy to make it something spectacular."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/green-hallway.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-138" title="green-hallway" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/green-hallway.jpg" alt="" width="600" height="449" /></a>[/caption]

</div>
Rather than placing a ficus in the corner, wouldn't you rather have a mobile hedge as part of your home or office architecture?

[caption id="attachment_136" align="alignnone" width="528" caption="This hedge is for your indoor design, and can be moved about at will."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/moving-hedge1.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-136" title="moving-hedge1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/moving-hedge1.jpg" alt="" width="528" height="418" /></a>[/caption]

How about a wall of coleus to add color and clean the air of your lobby area?

[caption id="attachment_137" align="alignnone" width="600" caption="Help your clients breath easy with this structural accent."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/coleus-wall.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-137" title="coleus-wall" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/coleus-wall.jpg" alt="" width="600" height="450" /></a>[/caption]

These structural plants are from <a title="Green Works" href="http://www.greenwork.se/about.html" target="_blank">Green Works</a>, and come in a nice variety of plant life, shape, and form. At the forefront of eco-friendly and environmentally sound architecture, Gelotte Hommas is excited to see  yet another amazing element added to the ingenuity of such projects.

If you’re looking to design a green commercial or residential property, let our firm handle it for you. Gelotte Hommas is well versed in eco-friendly architecture and can create a modern, well-designed space that perfectly fits your needs while working to preserve and protect the Earth around it. <a title="Gelotte Hommas" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/contact-us/" target="_blank">Contact us today for more information</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Johan Sundberg’s Bergman Werntoft House</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/16/johan-sundbergs-bergman-werntoft-house/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 00:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=319</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Just recently we saw photos of <a title="home design" href="http://www.contemporist.com/2011/06/13/bergman-werntoft-house-by-johan-sundberg/" target="_blank">Johan Sundberg’s Bergman Werntoft House in Sweden</a> in the Contemporist. We love the style and design of this modern space, that has more of the open and airy appeal of a cabin rather than the harsher, more clinical approach that some modern spaces have.
<div id="attachment_1487">

[caption id="attachment_321" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="The extensive use of gorgeous wood and glass walls gives this home a casual elegance"]<a href="http://www.contemporist.com/2011/06/13/bergman-werntoft-house-by-johan-sundberg/"><img class="size-full wp-image-321" title="Bergman Werntoft House by Johan Sundberg" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/bw_1.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="353" /></a>[/caption]

Rather than using metal and streamlined materials, Sundberg kept the space at ease with wood and other natural elements, making it feel more homey than industrial.

</div>
<div id="attachment_1488">

[caption id="attachment_320" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="Spacious windows bring the outside into this natural space."]<a href="http://www.contemporist.com/2011/06/13/bergman-werntoft-house-by-johan-sundberg/"><img class="size-full wp-image-320" title="Bergman Werntoft House by Johan Sundberg" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/bw_2.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="372" /></a>[/caption]

</div>
Floor to ceiling windows and skylights tie each room in the home to the outdoors. Along with exposed wooden walls in the home and the natural aesthetic of the decor, the space becomes not just a reflection of nature, but a part of it.

To see more photos of the space, how it relates to nature, and how each nook within the home serves a purpose, <a title="full article" href="http://www.contemporist.com/2011/06/13/bergman-werntoft-house-by-johan-sundberg/" target="_blank">read the full article</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>319</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-06-16 00:00:28</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>johan-sundbergs-bergman-werntoft-house</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	<item>
		<title>An Architect’s Simple Solution for Japanese Disaster Survivors</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/04/01/an-architects-simple-solution-for-japanese-disaster-survivors/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Apr 2011 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=323</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s impossible to watch the news these days and not be affected by the horrifying disasters that have hit Japan, and are still unfolding. We were interested to see the very innovative response from acclaimed Japanese architect <a href="http://www.shigerubanarchitects.com/" target="_blank">Shigeru Ban</a>.

He’s famous for using paper to build extremely sturdy buildings that are also inexpensive to erect. The paper is rolled into logs that are extremely sturdy, yet inexpensive to make, and can easily be recycled when (or if) the building is disassembled. He’s applied this concept to help shelter victims of natural disaster around the world and to create inexpensive. His first such project was designing shelters for the victims of the Kobe Earthquake in 1995.

In a recent <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/24/garden/24qna.html" target="_blank">interview in the <em>New York Times</em></a> Ban said that in the current Japanese disaster, he’s creating simple partitions to provide some privacy for survivors who are staying in emergency shelters.

Apparently, the “walls” are frames made of his famous paper rolls, with white curtains hanging in between. Ban’s website has a descriptions and photos of the partitions and some discussion of the design process (in Japanese and English).

[caption id="attachment_324" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="Ban&#039;s partitions need no wooden joints or braces."]<a href="http://www.shigerubanarchitects.com/SBA_NEWS/SBA_news_5.htm"><img class="size-full wp-image-324" title="ban-partitions-materials_1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/ban-partitions-materials_1.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="266" /></a>[/caption]

[caption id="attachment_325" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="The partitions are very easy to assemble."]<a href="http://www.shigerubanarchitects.com/SBA_NEWS/SBA_news_5.htm"><img class="size-full wp-image-325" title="ban-partitions-2" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/ban-partitions-2.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="266" /></a>[/caption]

[caption id="attachment_326" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="Once assembled the occupant has a very real sense of privacy and safety"]<a href="http://www.shigerubanarchitects.com/SBA_NEWS/SBA_news_5.htm"><img class="size-full wp-image-326" title="ban-partitions-3" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/ban-partitions-3.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="267" /></a>[/caption]

<a href="http://www.shigerubanarchitects.com/SBA_NEWS/SBA_news_5.htm"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-327" title="ban-partitions-4" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/ban-partitions-4.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="266" /></a>

A bank account has been set up in Japan specifically for donations to help fund creation of these partitions. Here’s the information from <a href="http://www.shigerubanarchitects.com/SBA_NEWS/SBA_news_5.htm" target="_blank">Ban’s website</a>:

Donations made to the following account are very much appreciated.

Bank:                The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd.
Branch:             Higashi Matsubara Branch
Account Name:   Voluntary Architects Network
Account No.:       3636723 (Futsuu)
Swift Code:         BOTKJPJT
Bank Address:     5-2-18 Matsubara, Setagaya, Tokyo, Japan

海外からのお振込みの場合、IBANコードは必要ありません。
IBAN code is not necessary for transactions from overseas.

Along with your contribution, please send us your contact information to our e-mail ( van@shigerubanarchitects.com ) or FAX (+81 3 3324 6789) for updates about this project.

You can also make a donation to a general fund for Japanese disaster relief at the <a href="https://american.redcross.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=ggl_main&amp;gclid=CP3b9oKK_KcCFcns7QodlSo1rQ" target="_blank">American Red Cross website</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Curtis Gelotte in October Seattle Homes &#038; Lifestyles</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/10/11/curtis-gelotte-in-october-seattle-homes-lifestyles/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Oct 2010 00:00:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=351</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="http://gelottehommas.com/" href="http://gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture’s</a> own <a title="http://gelottehommas.com/bio_gelotte.html" href="http://gelottehommas.com/bio_gelotte.html" target="_blank">Curtis Gelotte</a> is featured in the <a title="http://www.seattlehomesmag.com/article/scene-october-2010" href="http://www.seattlehomesmag.com/article/scene-october-2010" target="_blank">October 2010 “Scene”</a> in the new<a title="http://seattlehomesmag.com" href="http://seattlehomesmag.com/" target="_blank">Seattle Homes &amp; Lifestyles</a> for an appearance at the <a title="http://www.auctionofwashingtonwines.org/" href="http://www.auctionofwashingtonwines.org/" target="_blank">2010 Auction of Washington Wines</a> in August.

[caption id="attachment_352" align="aligncenter" width="485" caption="Curtis Gelotte (far right) is pictured with Seattle Homes &amp; Lifestyles&#039; Rachel Gallaher and Robinson Fralick; Photo by Whitman Dewey-Smith for Team Photogenic 2010 via seattlehomesmag.com"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/curtisgelotte_seattlemag.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-352" title="CurtisGelotte_seattlemag" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/curtisgelotte_seattlemag.jpg" alt="" width="485" height="360" /></a>[/caption]

Mr. Gelotte joined SH&amp;L staffers at the auction weekend’s Barrel Auction and Picnic with the Winemakers at <a title="http://www.ste-michelle.com/" href="http://www.ste-michelle.com/" target="_blank">Chateau Ste. Michelle</a> in Woodinville, Wash. The event raised raised $1.4 million for uncompensated care at <a title="http://www.seattlechildrens.org/" href="http://www.seattlechildrens.org/" target="_blank">Seattle Children’s Hospital</a> and the <a title="http://washingtonwine.org" href="http://washingtonwine.org/" target="_blank">Washington Wine Education Foundation</a>. Check out the October<a title="http://www.seattlehomesmag.com/issue/shl-october-2010" href="http://www.seattlehomesmag.com/issue/shl-october-2010" target="_blank">“Favorite Spaces” issue</a> of Seattle Homes &amp; Lifestyles for design inspiration throughout the home.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Vote for Gelotte Hommas Wild Pumpkin Design</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/10/27/vote-for-gelotte-hommas-wild-pumpkin-design/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Oct 2010 20:51:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=355</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="http://gelottehommas.com/" href="http://gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> needs your vote to help project manager Curt Peterson win a <a title="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/" href="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/" target="_blank">pumpkin design contest</a> sponsored by <a title="http://www.thisoldhouse.com/toh" href="http://www.thisoldhouse.com/toh" target="_blank">This Old House</a>. Curt’s pumpkin sculpture, “The Gatekeeper,” appears as one of the magazine’s <a title="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/" href="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/" target="_blank">99 Wild Pumpkins</a> competing for a spot in the Top 25, which will be announced online Oct. 29. The #1 pumpkin design will be chosen by the editors of <a title="http://thisoldhouse.com/" href="http://thisoldhouse.com/" target="_blank">This Old House</a>. To sculpt the pumpkin, Curt used a carving knife, clay loop tools, and an X-Acto blade. The whole work took him four hours to complete.

[caption id="attachment_356" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="Pumpkin carved by our very own Curt Peterson"]<a href="http://gelottehommas.com/Pumpkins.html"><img class="size-full wp-image-356" title="Curt Peterson pumpkin carving 2010" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/curt2010pumpkin-768x1024.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="746" /></a>[/caption]

<a title="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com" href="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/" target="_blank">Vote</a> by giving Curt’s “The Gatekeeper” pumpkin sculpture a 100 rating. The site doesn’t provide a unique web address to Curt’s page, but <a title="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/pumpkincarving/index.jsp" href="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/pumpkincarving/index.jsp" target="_blank">click through the wild pumpkin designs</a> until you find the intimidating “Gatekeeper.” Check back at the <a title="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas blog</a> next week to see if Curt makes the Top 25. Great job, Curt!

Want to design a unique pumpkin of your own? Check out these easy <a title="http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/Pumpkin-Carving-Ideas-From-Around-the-Smithsonian.html?c=y&amp;page=5&amp;navigation=thumb" href="http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/Pumpkin-Carving-Ideas-From-Around-the-Smithsonian.html?c=y&amp;page=5&amp;navigation=thumb" target="_blank">pumpkin-carving patterns from around the Smithsonian Institute</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Architecture-Inspired Carved Pumpkin Wins Contest</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/11/01/architecture-inspired-carved-pumpkin-wins-contest/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Nov 2010 00:00:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=359</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[While <a title="http://gelottehommas.com/" href="http://gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> project manager Curt Peterson’s <a title="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/events-and-happenings/vote-for-gelotte-hommas-wild-pumpkin-design/" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/events-and-happenings/vote-for-gelotte-hommas-wild-pumpkin-design/" target="_blank">“Gatekeeper” pumpkin sculpture</a>didn’t make the final cut, an amazing architecture-inspired carved pumpkin won <a title="http://www.thisoldhouse.com/toh/photos/0,,20436998,00.html?xid=ugc-2010-pumpkincontest-winners" href="http://www.thisoldhouse.com/toh/photos/0,,20436998,00.html?xid=ugc-2010-pumpkincontest-winners" target="_blank">This Old House’s 2010 pumpkin-carving contest</a> based on user voting and editorial judgment.

[caption id="attachment_360" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="&quot;Haunted Carousel&quot; photo via thisoldhouse.com"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/carouselpumpkin.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-360" title="carouselpumpkin" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/carouselpumpkin.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="400" /></a>[/caption]

This <a title="http://www.thisoldhouse.com/toh/photos/0,,20436998_20869331,00.html" href="http://www.thisoldhouse.com/toh/photos/0,,20436998_20869331,00.html" target="_blank">haunted carousel carved pumpkin</a> created by Karyn T. of Fort Worth, Tex., was a hit with the home improvement magazine’s readers and judges and took home the $500 grand prize. Says the pumpkin’s creator:
<blockquote>“I found the perfect sized pumpkin to do an all-around design, and had this one tucked in the back of a folder. The top is held up by skewers, and when the wind blew through the pumpkin it gave the illusion of it moving. It was the hit of the neighborhood!”</blockquote>
Thanks to everyone who voted for <a title="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/events-and-happenings/vote-for-gelotte-hommas-wild-pumpkin-design/" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/events-and-happenings/vote-for-gelotte-hommas-wild-pumpkin-design/" target="_blank">Curt’s design</a>, which appeared as one of the <a title="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/pumpkincarving/" href="http://youroldhouse.thisoldhouse.com/pumpkincarving/" target="_blank">Top 99 contest entries</a>, and best of luck next year.

Stay in touch with <a title="http://gelottehommas.com/" href="http://gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> by signing up to receive blog posts and information via <a title="http://feedburner.google.com/fb/a/mailverify?uri=gelottehommas" href="http://feedburner.google.com/fb/a/mailverify?uri=gelottehommas" target="_blank">e-mail</a> or <a title="http://feeds.feedburner.com/gelottehommas" href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/gelottehommas" target="_blank">RSS feed</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Fall Decor Highlights Architecture</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/09/27/fall-decor-highlights-architecture/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Sep 2010 21:05:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=364</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="http://interiordec.about.com/od/fallindex/ig/Fall-Decorations-for-Outside/" href="http://interiordec.about.com/od/fallindex/ig/Fall-Decorations-for-Outside/" target="_blank"><strong>Highlight your home’s architecture with</strong><strong> fall decor</strong></a> to welcome the season and express your style. <strong>Fall decor</strong>such as pumpkins, wreaths, baskets, and other natural elements and lighting will draw attention to your home’s best architectural features and create a friendly greeting for trick-or-treaters and out-of-town guests.

Consider <strong>adding fall decor to these home architectural elements</strong>:
<ul>
	<li>stairs

[caption id="attachment_365" align="alignright" width="250" caption="Bittersweet wreath via www.blommafinds.com"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/fallwreath.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-365" title="fallwreath" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2011/12/fallwreath.jpg" alt="" width="250" height="333" /></a>[/caption]</li>
	<li>fence posts</li>
	<li>front porch</li>
	<li>front door</li>
	<li>windows</li>
	<li>columns</li>
	<li>benches</li>
</ul>
Check out <a title="http://www.marthastewart.com/photogallery/pumpkins" href="http://www.marthastewart.com/photogallery/pumpkins" target="_blank">Martha Stewart’s pumpkin-carving and decorating ideas</a> for more ways to add seasonal touches to your home’s architecture.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Responsive Architecture Hot Topic at 2010 Solar Decathlon</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/10/26/responsive-architecture-hot-topic-at-2010-solar-decathlon/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Oct 2010 00:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=394</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Responsive architecture</strong>, or buildings that adapt to different environmental conditions, <strong>was a hot topic at the <a title="http://greensource.construction.com/features/currents/2010/1009_Madrid_Hosts_Solar_Decathlon.asp" href="http://greensource.construction.com/features/currents/2010/1009_Madrid_Hosts_Solar_Decathlon.asp" target="_blank">2010 Solar Decathlon</a>,</strong> the annual collegiate competition that focuses on solar power and green building techniques. Held this year in Madrid, Spain, Virginia Tech’s <a title="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" href="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" target="_blank">Lumenhaus</a> took top honors for its innovative 100% solar-powered, zero-energy model home.

How did they do it? Smart use of solar power, technology, and architectural knowledge. <a title="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" href="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" target="_self">Lumenhaus</a> is designed as an “open pavilion” with movable walls and solar panels that shift to maximize energy efficiency and create the right temperature inside, controlled by an automated system. The open design was inspired by the glass-pavilion architecture of the modernist masterpiece <a title="http://www.farnsworthhouse.org/index.htm" href="http://www.farnsworthhouse.org/index.htm" target="_blank">Farnsworth House</a> designed by Mies van der Rohe, which today functions as a museum and historic site in its original location in Illinois. <a title="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" href="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" target="_blank">Lumenhaus</a> will be on display Nov. 17-19 at the <a title="http://www.greenbuildexpo.org/Home.aspx" href="http://www.greenbuildexpo.org/Home.aspx" target="_blank">Greenbuild International Conference and Expo</a> in Chicago.

Learn more about <a title="http://www.energysavers.gov/your_home/designing_remodeling/index.cfm/mytopic=10270" href="http://www.energysavers.gov/your_home/designing_remodeling/index.cfm/mytopic=10270" target="_blank">passive solar home design</a> from this <a title="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OSrTKklGOI&amp;feature=mfu_in_order&amp;playnext=1&amp;videos=c5y3vZLwWHQ" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OSrTKklGOI&amp;feature=mfu_in_order&amp;playnext=1&amp;videos=c5y3vZLwWHQ" target="_blank">You Tube video about Lumenhaus</a>:

[youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OSrTKklGOI&w=640&h=360]

Leave us a comment and let us know which solar power applications used in <a title="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" href="http://www.lumenhaus.com/eu/" target="_blank">Lumenhaus</a> are you most interested in?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An Essential Element to the American Dream: Owning A Home</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/14/an-essential-element-to-the-american-dream-owning-a-home/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 14 Jun 2011 00:00:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=489</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Gelotte Hommas specializes in custom residential architecture because we know how important having your home is to you, and we want it to be custom made to suit you and your needs.<a title="Home Ownership and the American Dream" href="http://www.nahb.org/news_details.aspx?newsID=12823" target="_blank"> In a way, we’re just helping you to fulfill the American Dream, as owning a home is essential to fulfilling that goal</a>.

[caption id="attachment_490" align="aligncenter" width="490" caption="his isn&#039;t just a home--it&#039;s an investment."]<a href="http://gelottehommas.com/completed/Woodinville_Street_of_Dreams.html"><img class="size-full wp-image-490" title="large_9" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_91.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>[/caption]

The American Dream of prosperity, freedom, and comfort, has many elements, but even in the struggling house market of today, it appears that renters, non-home owners, and home owners all believe that owning a home is still an essential element to this ideal in our culture. Home ownership is still looked upon as one of the best investments you can make, and if you’re already a homeowner, then you know how rewarding the experience can be.

Add to the value of your home by upgrading and renovating your space. You can do this easily by upgrading the kitchen and the bathrooms, rooms that buyers look at more closely than others, or by adding accessory buildings with the help of Gelotte Hommas.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>GHA announced as an award of Merit winner for the 2011 Gold Nuggets</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/15/gha-announced-as-an-award-of-merit-winner-for-the-2011-gold-nuggets/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Jun 2011 00:00:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=518</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The <strong><em><a href="http://www.pcbc.com/GoldNugget/merit.html">Gold Nugget Awards</a></em> are the largest award ceremony of it’s kind – not to mention the longest running. Based in California, the awards are geared to give recognition to exceptional individuals in the areas of design, planning and development.</strong>

We are very honored to announce that our project <strong><em><a href="http://www.gelottehommas.com/contemp/07_lakefront_splendor.html">Lakefront Splendor</a></em> is one of seven merit awards in Category 10 – Renovated or Restored Single Hous</strong><strong>e or</strong><strong>Project.</strong><strong>
This is truly an amazing home.</strong>

[caption id="attachment_519" align="aligncenter" width="490" caption="Lakefront Splendor - 2011 Merit Award Winner"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_12.png"><img class="size-full wp-image-519" title="Lakefront Splendor" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_12.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>[/caption]

<strong>The Grand award winners will be chosen out of the Merit Award winners for each catergory on June 23rd.
Check out the rest of the Merit winners by <a href="http://www.pcbc.com/GoldNugget/merit.html">clicking here</a>.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tree Inspired Restaurant Design</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/12/tree-inspired-restaurant-design/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Jun 2011 00:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=521</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[While exploring some of the other innovations in green design on the<a title="Contemporist" href="http://www.contemporist.com/2011/06/02/tree-restaurant-by-koichi-takada-architects/#more-31356" target="_blank"> Contemporist</a>, we found this wonderful design for a restaurant in Sydney from Koichi Takada Architects. The center of the restaurant is designed to look like a giant tree, inspired by the cherry trees that the architects are so familiar with.

[caption id="attachment_522" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="The center of the restaurant mimics the trunk of a giant tree"]<a href="http://www.contemporist.com/2011/06/02/tree-restaurant-by-koichi-takada-architects/#more-31356"><img class="size-full wp-image-522" title="tree-restaurant" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/tree-restaurant.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="373" /></a>[/caption]

The space has a natural and organic feel to it thanks to the tree design, while still maintaining the simple and chic lines of a modern space. As you can see from the picture, guests at the bar can feel that they truly are sitting under the branches of a giant tree towering over them while they enjoy a martini or an appetizer.

As nature becomes more and more important to architects around the world, more firms are getting inventive with their creative use of not only eco-friendly products, but design itself as found in nature. What do you think of this trend?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>UPDATE: Seattle Architect Foundation exhibit to feature Gelotte Hommas</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/06/update-seattle-architect-foundation-exhibit-to-feature-gelotte-hommas/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 06 Jun 2011 00:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=524</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Seattle Architecture Foundation is hosting their <a title="Architecture Model Exhibit in Seattle" href="http://seattlearchitecture.org/events_annualexhibit.html" target="_blank">14th Annual Architecture Model Exhibit</a>, where Gelotte Hommas will be one of the featured exhibits.

[caption id="attachment_525" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="&quot;An Imagined History&quot;"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/2007-05-18-014.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-525" title="OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/2007-05-18-014.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="420" /></a>[/caption]

We are particularly excited to showcase this particular project as there could not be a better fit for the SAF theme this year of  “Transitions: Transforming Place, Process, and Practice”.
The event outlines what all this entails in their description:
<blockquote><strong>Place: </strong>The work shown plays a role in the transition of place. These projects both shape and are shaped by their given context.
<strong>Process: </strong>The models shown fit into the architectural design process and tell a bigger story about design and the transitions throughout a project’s life that shape its final form.
<strong>Practice: </strong>The architecture industry has constantly reinvented itself in response to technology, economic realities and new movements. Old ideas are constantly challenged and new ideas are developed and tested.</blockquote>
We don’t want to give away too much, but we will say that this is truly a unique project with numerous interesting aspects and we are very excited to be sharing it with all of you. The exhibit’s Opening Reception is June 17th; you can <a title="Tickets" href="http://seattlearchitecture.org/events_annualexhibit.html" target="_blank">purchase tickets now</a>. The exhibit will be open from June 21st – 24th at Pacific Place in Seattle. We will see you there!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>524</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-06-06 00:00:24</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-06-06 00:00:24</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

	<item>
		<title>See the Final Touches on One of Gelotte Hommas’s Projects</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/05/see-the-final-touches-on-one-of-gelotte-hommass-projects/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 05 Jun 2011 00:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=527</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As you know, the homeowner of the Sammamish Remodel that Gelotte Hommas has been working on has been helping to document our careful progress through videos that have been placed on <a title="Videos on the remodel" href="http://www.youtube.com/profile?user=wck0127#p/u/0/ceY1U5ivyiY" target="_blank">Youtube</a>. You can visually watch as the remodel comes to life and comes together, <a title="sammamish remodel" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/in-progress/snow-falls-on-sammamish-remodel-in-progress/" target="_blank">through the snow</a> and through clearer skies.

Just three weeks ago, a new video was posted that shows further progress and some of the final touches as they are added to the home. You can see it, as well as the previous videos that tell the story of the space as it slowly develops into a finished area.

[youtube http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ceY1U5ivyiY]

Watching a time lapse video helps to give viewers a sense of the process and the time it takes to create a new space or to adapt an old one. Watching these videos is a wonderful idea for those of you ready to undergo a remodel, so you can see a bit of the progress and process that will be involved. If you have further questions on remodeling your home, please contact us at <a title="contact us" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/contact-us/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Check Out Architectural Attractions from Around the World</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/12/21/check-out-architectural-attractions-from-around-the-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Dec 2010 00:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=534</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If the holidays have you dreaming of faraway destinations, add these <a href="http://www.catalogs.com/info/bestof/top-10-architectural-attractions-off-the-beaten-path" target="_blank">architectural attractions from around the world</a> to your list:
<ol>
	<li>Chapelle Notre Dame du Haut de Ronchamp, France</li>
	<li>Casa Luis Barragan, Mexico City, Mexico</li>
	<li>Ise Grand Shrine, Ise, Japan</li>
	<li>Church of Light, Osaka, Japan</li>
	<li>Eglise Notre Dame du Raincy, Le Raincy, France</li>
	<li>Arcosanti, Arizona</li>
	<li>Pueblo Adobe Houses, Taos, New Mexico</li>
	<li>Thermal Bath House, Vals, Switzerland</li>
	<li>Maison de Verre, Paris, France</li>
	<li>Church of Panagia Paraportiani, Mykonos, Greece</li>
</ol>
We think the Thermal Bath House in Vals, Switzerland, provides some great inspiration for a residential spa. Contact <a href="http://gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> in Bellevue, Wash., to get this look in your own home.

[caption id="attachment_535" align="aligncenter" width="406" caption="Thermal Bath House, Vals, Switzerland; Image via catalogs.com"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/8_thermal-bath-house-1.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-535" title="8_Thermal-bath-house-1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/8_thermal-bath-house-1.jpg" alt="" width="406" height="500" /></a>[/caption]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Prairie House in the Virginia Woods</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/08/10/prairie-house-in-the-virginia-woods/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Aug 2010 00:00:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=537</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairie_1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-539" title="prairie_1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairie_1.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="239" /></a>

<a title="http://gelottehommas.com/" href="http://gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> draws inspiration from legendary architect Frank Lloyd Wright and his signature Prairie style designs, which are reflected in our <a title="http://www.gelottehommas.com/traditional/02_prairie_house.html#" href="http://gelottehommas.com/prairie-style-house-in-virginia-woods.html" target="_blank">“Prairie House in the Virginia Woods” project</a>, consisting of a 3,000 square-foot main house and 550 square-foot guest house (above). The traditional home, located in Charlottesville, Virginia, displays the horizontal lines, low-perched roof, and open floor plan that characterize Prairie style.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairielivingroom.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-542" title="prairielivingroom" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairielivingroom.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="238" /></a>

The colors and materials in the home were chosen to match the landscape.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairiewindow.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-538" title="prairiewindow" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairiewindow.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="240" /></a>

“Wisteria” detailing is featured on interior and exterior doors as well as in the tile work in the showers.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairiekitchen1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-541" title="prairiekitchen1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairiekitchen1.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="240" /></a>

Increasing functionality, the dining room is flanked by a built-in shelf that can be used as a buffet or folded up and hidden away.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairiekitchen.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-540" title="prairiekitchen" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/prairiekitchen.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="239" /></a>

Modern stainless steel appliances contrast beautifully with the warm, honey-colored cabinets, mouldings, and floors.

<strong>Photography</strong>: Philip Beaurline

<strong>Builder</strong>: <a href="http://www.shelterltd.com/" target="_blank">Shelter Associates Ltd.</a>

For further reading, check out the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation <a title="http://www.franklloydwright.org/fllwf_web_091104/Home.html" href="http://www.franklloydwright.org." target="_blank">here</a>, and read <a title="http://architecture.about.com/od/periodsstyles/ig/House-Styles/The-Robie-House.htm" href="http://architecture.about.com/od/periodsstyles/ig/House-Styles/The-Robie-House.htm" target="_blank">this article</a> about his Prairie style designs.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Stimulus for Architecture Students</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/04/30/stimulus-for-architecture-students/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Apr 2010 00:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=544</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We found an interesting commentary in ArchitectMagazine.com on a particularly poignant predicament being faced by today’s architecture students upon graduating into an job environment rife with recession pains.

As editor Ned Cramer writes, “Job stats for building design and construction look even worse than the national average. A survey by AIA Nevada, for instance, reports 65 percent industry unemployment in Las Vegas…But an exquisite kind of pain is reserved for current architecture students and recent grads, who are entering the workforce with profoundly limited prospects in their chosen profession.”

[caption id="attachment_545" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Architecture is an almost universal language of design"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/arch-300x224.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-545" title="arch-300x224" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/arch-300x224.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="224" /></a>[/caption]

Cramer bemoans the fact that the initial government stimulus package had many Americans “dreaming up WPA-style programs to get architects back to work, making an honest living by designing solutions to some of our country’s most pressing problems. That hasn’t happened, at least not nearly to the degree so many of us had hoped.”

“Where are all the commissions for new, net zero community centers, schools, libraries, post offices, and train stations? Why aren’t firms hiring again, flush with government projects? Just as importantly, where are the 21st century equivalents of FDR’s HABS (the Historic American Buildings Survey), which sent out-of-work architects around the country to draw up plans of national landmarks?

At this point, I’m highly doubtful that the federal government will be coming to architecture’s rescue…but the profession must do its best to bridge the gap. Our first priority should be fostering the next generation, ensuring that a lack of jobs today doesn’t result in mass defections of skill and passion to other, less beleaguered professions. The talent emerging from our architecture schools is too valuable to waste.”

How can you help? Check out “<a href="http://www.architectmagazine.com/education/stimulus-for-students.aspx" target="_blank">Stimulus for Students</a>” to see how you can help these young creatives make a difference.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Ideas for Using Architectural Salvage</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/10/13/ideas-for-using-architectural-salvage/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Oct 2010 00:00:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=547</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A recent <a title="http://www.oldhouseonline.com/salvage-renewal-in-a-seattle-foursquare/" href="http://www.oldhouseonline.com/salvage-renewal-in-a-seattle-foursquare/" target="_blank">Seattle remodel</a> featured in Old House magazine presents some great ideas for using architectural salvage to create a historic feel inside your home. The feature describes how Robin Warner and Rich Moyer lovingly restored a 1908 Foursquare in Seattle’s Nob Hill neighborhood to its former glory with architectural salvage and historically accurate new construction.

The historic home had been updated throughout the years to reflect the trends of the day, but much of its original look had been covered over. Underneath it all, the couple found inspiration from the original structure of the home. Chief among Robin’s vision for the home was including architectural salvage collected over the years as well as found items to create an aged look to match the home’s architecture.

<strong>Ideas for Using Salvaged Materials</strong>
<ul>
	<li>antique buffet turned kitchen island&nbsp;
<div id="attachment_821">

[caption id="attachment_548" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="Image via oldhouseonline.com"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/seattle-foursquare-kitchen-overview.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-548" title="seattle-foursquare-kitchen-overview" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/seattle-foursquare-kitchen-overview.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="419" /></a>[/caption]

Image via oldhouseonline.com

</div></li>
	<li>antique and vintage light fixtures</li>
	<li>salvaged laundry sink</li>
	<li>salvaged leaded glass window in staircase</li>
	<li>salvaged French doors</li>
</ul>
Though architectural salvage doesn’t always come ready-to-use, the repair work necessary pays off in lovingly restored and age-appropriate interiors. Check out Old House’s <a title="http://www.oldhouseonline.com/salvage-shopping-tips/" href="http://www.oldhouseonline.com/salvage-shopping-tips/" target="_blank">“Salvage Shopping Tips”</a> for more renovation style.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Inspired by Frank Lloyd Wright</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/03/04/inspired-by-frank-lloyd-wright/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 04 Mar 2010 00:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=550</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The <a title="Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation" href="http://www.franklloydwright.org/" target="_blank">Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation</a> recently paid $48,800 for the collection of Wright photographs, correspondence and select building plans at a Los Angeles auction, the Associated Press reports.

The foundation seeks to preserve the architect’s legacy, and the items purchased at auction include photos of Wright buildings that no longer exist, including his home and the demolished Imperial Hotel in Tokyo, according to the Associated Press.

We’ve created homes influenced by Wright, including this Virginia prairie-style home with a 3,000-square-foot main house and 550-square-foot guest house.

[caption id="attachment_551" align="aligncenter" width="490" caption="Prairie House in the Virginia Woods"]<a href="http://gelottehommas.com/completed/Prairie%20House%20in%20the%20Virginia%20Woods.html"><img class="size-full wp-image-551" title="large_8" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_81.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>[/caption]

The builder, Shelter Associates Ltd., helped create a home with simple, beautiful lines and these other key details:

• Choice of colors and materials matches the landscape

• “Wisteria” detailing featured on interior and exterior doors as well as the tile work in the showers

• Dining room side of kitchen cabinet can be used as a buffet or the shelf can be folded up and hidden away

In what ways does Wright’s architecture appeal to you?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Seattle thinking about reuse. Good or bad?</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2010/05/27/553/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 May 2010 00:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=553</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Could adapting office buildings to residential be a viable solution in downtown Seattle? That’s a question<a href="http://www.publicola.net/2010/05/19/could-adapting-office-buildings-to-residential-work-in-seattle/">Publicola.com</a> recently asked given the city of Seattle’s goal of bringing more housing to downtown.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/seattle-300x225.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-554" title="seattle-300x225" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/seattle-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>

The one recent example of a large-scale conversion from office to residential in Seattle that the author cites as working: The Cobb, at 4th and University.

And although adaptive reuse is a buzzword of late, the author writes that “In Seattle, both the economics and market are totally different, and it will likely be rare for all the factors required to make conversion from large-scale office to housing attractive to align. It worked at The Cobb mainly because the building is historic—it had become obsolete for modern offices and it qualified for historic tax-credit financing. In most cases, simply getting office floorplates to lay out well for residential units would be a serious encumbrance.”

What do you think? Would it be a smart strategy for urban planners and developers to keep the possibilities of reuse in mind? Could this truly triumph over demolition? <a href="http://www.publicola.net/2010/05/19/could-adapting-office-buildings-to-residential-work-in-seattle/" target="_blank">Check out Publicola.com to voice your opinion</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Discover Fallen Maples</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/08/19/discover-fallen-maples/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 19 Aug 2011 00:00:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=439</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Fallen Maples, a home designed by<a title="Gelotte Hommas Architecture" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/about/" target="_blank"> Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a>, is set to be featured in the next issue of 425 Magazine. <a title="Fallen Maples" href="http://gelottehommas.com/northwest/10_fallen_maples.html" target="_blank">Fallen Maples</a> is the perfect example of what Gelotte Hommas stands for–Innovative green architecture that is eco-friendly while maintaining all functionality and extreme beauty.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_1.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-440" title="large_1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_1.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_9.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-444" title="large_9" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_9.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>

Fallen Maples is located in the prestigious Grand Ridge Drive custom home neighborhood of Issaquah Highlands, which features homes on two or more acres of beautiful, wooded lots. The surrounding woods served as great inspiration and a great source for the home, as Gelotte Hommas decided to put the fallen trees to good use.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_6.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-448" title="large_6" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_6.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_3.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-446" title="large_3" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_3.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>

This 4,600 square foot home was built using completely reclaimed wood, and great features like the dining table, cabinets, and interior wood trim are made from fallen trees that were pulled from the property. The open, spacious and  light-filled great room makes the woodland meadow around the home a focal point, showcasing it’s beauty both inside the home and out.

<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_5.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-442" title="large_5" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_5.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-441" title="large_2" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_2.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" />

The environmentally conscious ideals of Gelotte Hommas and the attention of the builder who brought the home to fruition, Roberts Wygal, earned Fallen Maples a 4-Star Built Green® certification. The home embodies beauty, eco-friendly design, and high functionality. Be sure to see it featured in the next 425 Magazine for an even closer look at this beautiful space.

<em>Photography by Michael Seidl. Interior design by Hilary Young Design Associates. </em>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tell Us About Your Architectural Style</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/08/15/tell-us-about-your-architectural-style/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 00:00:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=450</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Gelotte Hommas" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas Architecture</a> may design beautiful homes, but as the cliche adage goes, “beauty is in the eye of the beholder.” The homes we create are considered beautiful because of their expert craftsmanship and the techniques used to create them, but also because they contain elements that our clients are looking for in their home or building.

[caption id="attachment_451" align="aligncenter" width="490" caption="We want to know why you think this home is wonderful or not, not just whether or not you like it. Tell us what you think!"]<a href="http://gelottehommas.com/completed/Country_French_Manor.html"><img class="size-full wp-image-451" title="French Country Manor" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/large_11.png" alt="" width="490" height="380" /></a>[/caption]

With that being said, we want to know what your thoughts on architecture are. Architecture is something that is loved in many different forms and tastes, and we want to know which styles and ideals fit yours. We’ve created a simple survey with Survey Monkey that we would love for you to take to tell us about your preferences. <a href="http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/H9QRLSP">CLICK HERE to take the survey</a>. The questions are short and sweet and shouldn’t take but a minute or two to fill out. After the survey is complete, leave us a comment telling us that you took it, or commenting on what you love about Gelotte Hommas’s work, or about architecture as a whole.

We can’t wait to see your responses!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Architecture Behind the Bellevue Arts Museum</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/08/11/the-architecture-behind-the-bellevue-arts-museum/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 11 Aug 2011 00:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=454</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Bellevue Arts Museum is a creative mecca here in Bellevue Seattle. <a title="Bellevue Art Museum" href="http://www.bellevuearts.org/about_us/architecture.html" target="_blank">While we admire the art within and it provides great creative inspiration, the building itself is an architectural piece of art</a>.

The Bellevue Arts Museum is a compilation of glass, textured concrete, and aluminum that creates a bold and modern silhouette in the downtown scene. The building, set at three stories high and 36,000 square feet, provides a welcoming structure for art and visitors.

[caption id="attachment_455" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="The Bellevue Arts Museum"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/sam.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-455" title="SAM" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/sam.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="445" /></a>[/caption]

Steven Holl is the internationally renowned mind behind the beautiful structure, who decided to play with light in many imaginative ways within the structure. Skylights as well as the abundance of glass and metal make for a great deal of natural light and reflective surfaces in the museum. As you move through different periods of art, the light style changes, as if the building itself were to change with the subject being examined.

On your next visit to the Bellevue Art Museum, be sure to get a close look at the amazing structure, and not just the pieces within.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>See The Sites in Seattle As Dwell Goes On a Tour</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/08/05/see-the-sites-in-seattle-as-dwell-goes-on-a-tour/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Aug 2011 00:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=457</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Seeing the city that we love so much, Seattle, through the eyes of others who have an eye for design is a wonderful thing indeed.  Last year, <a title="Dwell City Scapes of Seattle" href="http://www.dwell.com/slideshows/seattle-part-1.html?slide=5&amp;c=y&amp;paused=true" target="_blank">Dwell took a little tour in the city</a> when they were writing about a home in the area. We love the various snap shots they included in a report that captures some of the great sculptures and architectural elements around the city that we wanted to share with you:

[caption id="attachment_458" align="aligncenter" width="482" caption="The iconic Space Needle"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/dwell-seattle-1.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-458" title="Dwell-Seattle-1" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/dwell-seattle-1.jpg" alt="" width="482" height="643" /></a>[/caption]

This shot from Olympic Sculpture Park shows off some of Seattle’s modern architecture along with it’s most iconic piece, the Space Needle.

[caption id="attachment_459" align="aligncenter" width="482" caption="Beverly Pepper&#039;s Peer&#039;s Ventaglio III"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/sculptures.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-459" title="sculptures" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/sculptures.jpg" alt="" width="482" height="643" /></a>[/caption]

There are plenty of inspiring sculptures in Seattle that serve as part of the creative process in the Seattle, lending themselves as muses to aspiring architects.

See the rest of <a title="Miyako Ohtake" href="http://www.dwell.com/people/miyoko-ohtake.html?tab=photographs&amp;c=y" target="_blank">Miyoko Ohtake</a>‘s photos in her <a title="Seattle City Tour" href="http://www.dwell.com/slideshows/seattle-part-1.html?slide=18&amp;c=y&amp;paused=true" target="_blank">pictorial article in Dwell</a>. What snap shots do you have of Seattle architecture and inspirational spaces?

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A New Style of Pool House</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/08/04/a-new-style-of-pool-house/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 04 Aug 2011 00:00:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=461</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We’ve told you a great deal about <a title="Accessory Buildings" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/green-and-sustainable/accessory-buildings-the-hottest-item-for-spring-and-summer/" target="_blank">accessory buildings</a> over the summer, but we’re guessing none of you thought to build your own little second home in your backyard. Interestingly enough, that’s exactly what a couple in Litchfield County, Connecticut decided to do.

[caption id="attachment_463" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="Shafer&#039;s client asked for an open and airy pool-house to work as a summer home."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/poolhouse.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-463" title="poolhouse" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/poolhouse.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="355" /></a>[/caption]

This couple lived in an extremely authentic 18th century home with low ceilings and other features that just made their home feel claustrophobic in the summer. <a title="Couple adds second home as accessory building" href="http://www.architecturaldigest.com/homes/homes/2011/08/john-cottrell-gil-schafer-connecticut-poolhouse-article" target="_blank">Rather than stay cramped up in the house, they asked Gil Shafer, to design them an accessory building that would work as a summer home with a pool</a>.

[caption id="attachment_462" align="aligncenter" width="476" caption="The inside and outside are designed to feel open, but aged, like this beautiful bathroom."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/poolhouse2.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-462" title="poolhouse2" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/poolhouse2.jpg" alt="" width="476" height="516" /></a>[/caption]

The space functions as a pool-house and a guest house that has a wonderful indoor/outdoor feel, is open and airy and the direct counterpart to the main house, and provides a light and open summer refuge for the homeowners. The building was designed to look older so that it could blend with the main house, while delicately still including many modern elements.

See more photos of this amazing home at <a title="Photo Credit" href="http://www.architecturaldigest.com/homes/homes/2011/08/john-cottrell-gil-schafer-connecticut-poolhouse-slideshow#slide=5" target="_blank">Architectural Digest</a>.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>GHA spends the evening celebrating with “The Best of 425!”</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/06/29/gha-spends-the-evening-celebrating-with-the-best-of-425/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Jun 2011 00:00:56 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Gelotte Hommas was voted the “Best Architect” in this month’s issue of <a href="http://www.425magazine.com/">425 Magazine</a>. We were excited and truly honored that all of you voted for us! We teamed up with a few of the other winners to throw a big thank you celebration. We would like to congratulate all of our fellow winners and give a special thanks to:<a href="http://www.craigwilliamsinteriors.com/">Craig Williams Interiors</a> (Best Interior Designer), <a href="http://www.hallwaygallery.com/index.php">Hallway Gallery</a> (Best Art Gallery), <a href="http://hamishanderson.com/">Hamish Anderson Custom Homes, Inc</a> (Best Builder), <a href="http://www.pinkabellacupcakes.com/">Pinkabella Cupcakes</a> (Best Dessert) and <a href="http://www.matthewscellars.com/">Matthews Estate</a> (Best Winery)<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/best_of_425.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-467" title="best_of_425" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/best_of_425.png" alt="" width="115" height="146" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Our own Eric Drivdahl featured in “40 under 40″!</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/07/29/our-own-eric-drivdahl-featured-in-40-under-40%e2%80%b3/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Jul 2011 00:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=469</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It would be easy for us to sit back and gloat as our own project manager Eric Drivdahl celebrates being honored in “<a href="http://www.housingzone.com/professionalremodeler/awards/professional-remodeler-40-under-40-eric-drivdahl">40 under 40</a>” by the magazine <em>Professional Builder, </em>but we will hold back.  After all we DID teach him all he knows about architecture, or was it the other way around?…

[caption id="attachment_470" align="aligncenter" width="250" caption="40 under 40"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/01_cover_0-jpg.jpeg"><img class="size-full wp-image-470" title="01_Cover_0.jpg" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/01_cover_0-jpg.jpeg" alt="" width="250" height="299" /></a>[/caption]

None the less, within the pages of this issue you will find 40 individuals (nationwide mind you) whom are both amazing and AMAZING (did we say that already?) in the field of architecture.

To quote the editor of the magazine David Barista “The 40 individuals featured on the following pages represent some of the brightest stars in the home-building industry — and they’re under the age of 40. We proudly present the home-building industry’s next generation of leadership.”

We couldn’t agree more David. You can check out the article <a href="http://www.housingzone.com/professionalremodeler/awards/professional-remodeler-40-under-40-eric-drivdahl">by clicking here </a>or go get the magazine on newstands.

Hat’s off to you Eric! All of us at GHA are very proud of you and we <strong>gladly</strong> accept your offer to present us all with a celebratory Starbucks! <em>(I’ll take a Frappucino)</em>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Seattle Arts Get Architectural Style Posted on July 29, 2011 By kmoore (Edit)</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/07/29/seattle-arts-get-architectural-style-posted-on-july-29-2011-by-kmoore-edit/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Jul 2011 00:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=473</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[An architect doesn’t just create a building or structure–They create a functional, large scale piece of art that people can admire for decades. Understanding the link between the creation of art and architecture is essential, and a new art exhibit at the <a title="Seattle Art Museum" href="http://www.seattleartmuseum.org/exhibit/exhibitDetail.asp?eventID=18930" target="_blank">Seattle Art Museum</a> is helping to make that understanding more tangible.

[caption id="attachment_474" align="aligncenter" width="560" caption="Mika Tajima is an artist that combines the art of architecture with other mediums in Seattle."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/mika-tajima-791x1024.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-474" title="mika-tajima-791x1024" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/mika-tajima-791x1024.jpg" alt="" width="560" height="724" /></a>[/caption]

<a title="Mika Tajima" href="http://www.dwell.com/events/mika-tajima-sam-next.html" target="_blank">Mika Tajima</a> is working to show the connections between art and architecture in her architectural art exhibit,<em>After the Martini Shot.</em> Tajima utilizes many mediums, “combining painting, sculpture, design, performance, video and sound” to create a new experience for her viewers, bringing them to experience art in a new way. The exhibit steps into the world of architecture as a “dynamic, architectural installation that explores the structure and language of painting as well as complicates the institutional history of displaying objects in a gallery.”

Head to the Seattle Art Museum to view this installation from Mika Tajima, and let us know which piece was your favorite in a comment. We can’t wait to hear what you think!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Network with Gelotte Hommas</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/07/22/network-with-gelotte-hommas/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 22 Jul 2011 00:00:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=477</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_478" align="aligncenter" width="298" caption="Get to know Gelotte Hommas on Facebook and Twitter!"]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/facebook-twitter.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-478" title="facebook-twitter" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/facebook-twitter.jpg" alt="" width="298" height="207" /></a>[/caption]

We strive to create beautiful spaces and beautiful homes at Gelotte Hommas, but we’re also working to get to know you. Did you know that you can network with Gelotte Hommas through social media? We not only have a blog to share with you on the latest in architecture in Seattle and with our firm, but we also are on Facebook and Twitter.

Through Facebook and Twitter, you’ll get timely updates on what is going on with Gelotte Hommas, and what projects we’re working on now. Our Facebook fans were some of the first to hear that we had won our several awards this year, and we were excited to be able to share it with those who have worked with us, who like our work, and who inspire us on a regular basis first.

We want to be able to network with you, so be sure to “<a title="Like us on Facebook" href="http://www.facebook.com/pages/Gelotte-Hommas-Architecture/106339399849" target="_blank">Like” us on Facebook</a> and to<a title="Follow Us on Twitter" href="http://twitter.com/#!/gelottehommas" target="_blank"> “Follow” us on Twitter</a>. We want to hear from you on what you think and what you want from Gelotte Hommas!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>On the Boards with Gelotte Hommas: The Bellevue Residence</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/07/21/on-the-boards-with-gelotte-hommas-the-bellevue-residence/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 Jul 2011 00:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=480</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Gelotte Hommas" href="http://blog.gelottehommas.com/" target="_blank">Gelotte Hommas</a> consistently has great projects in the works, and the Bellevue Residence, currently on our “<a title="On the Boards" href="http://gelottehommas.com/on_boards/17_bellevue_res.html#" target="_blank">On the Boards</a>” stage, is no exception.

[caption id="attachment_482" align="aligncenter" width="352" caption="We&#039;re working to create a beautiful home for this active family to enjoy for years to come."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/gh-bellevue-residence-front.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-482" title="GH-bellevue-residence-front" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/gh-bellevue-residence-front.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="223" /></a>[/caption]

This residential space is being designed to house a wonderful and casual lifestyle for an active family that will need space to enjoy life and to grow throughout the years. The home is nuzzled into a hillside, making it comfortable, cozy, and like it’s own everyday retreat.

[caption id="attachment_483" align="aligncenter" width="352" caption="Inside the home there will be plenty of space for the family to enjoy, including the indoor/outdoor great room."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/gh-bellevue-residence-main-floor-plan.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-483" title="GH-bellevue-residence-main-floor-plan" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/gh-bellevue-residence-main-floor-plan.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="354" /></a>[/caption]

As we plan the space, we’re maintaining our focus on facilitating open and flexible modern living within the home, making it efficient, spacious, and welcoming.

[caption id="attachment_481" align="aligncenter" width="352" caption="The site plan offers a look at the accessory and green spaces that the family will get to enjoy."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/gh-bellevue-residence-plan.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-481" title="GH-bellevue-residence-plan" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/gh-bellevue-residence-plan.jpg" alt="" width="352" height="223" /></a>[/caption]

To enhance the family atmosphere and to make the home open for entertaining, we’re enhancing the space with a large indoor/outdoor great room that will feature sliding panel doors to provide a 32′ clear opening, keeping the family in touch with the outdoors whenever they so please from the comfort of their home.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Take a Walking Tour of Seattle’s Architecture</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/07/15/take-a-walking-tour-of-seattles-architecture/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jul 2011 00:00:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.com/?p=486</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_487" align="alignleft" width="299" caption="The 1411 Fourth Avenue Building is a classic and iconic piece of architecture in Seattle."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/1411-fourth-avenue-building.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-487" title="1411-Fourth-Avenue-Building" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/1411-fourth-avenue-building.jpg" alt="" width="299" height="473" /></a>[/caption]

In Seattle it is easy to be distracted by the big names across the skyline. While we do have some iconic structures, like the Space Needle and Smith Tower, there is so much more to be found around Seattle. Take a walking tour of Seattle’s architecture to capture the real beauty in the buildings all around us.

Are you more of an independent soul that likes to explore without a tour guide? If so, then you can read the guidance of Maureen R. Elenga in her 2008 book, <em><a title="Seattle Architecture" href="http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/thearts/2008064590_architecture22.html" target="_blank">Seattle Architecture: A Walking Guide to Downtown</a></em>. That work will tell you about some of the wonderful buildings downtown, like the Seaboard Building or Rainer Square, along with its historical and architectural significance in the world today.

If you like having a tour guide along with you to answer questions and help you keep your way, then take one of the numerous tours offered by the <a title="Seattle Architecture" href="http://www.seattlearchitecture.org/tours_month.html#august" target="_blank">Seattle Architecture Foundation</a>. There are 19 tours available in August alone, and still 16 to go for the month of July.

Have you taken an architecture tour of Seattle yet?]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Become an Architect for Two Weeks in Seattle</title>
		<link>http://blog.gelottehommas.com/2011/07/08/become-an-architect-for-two-weeks-in-seattle/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Jul 2011 00:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>gelottehommas</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://gelottehommasblog.wordpress.com/?p=492</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_493" align="alignleft" width="200" caption="Were you born to be an architect? This 2 week course could be perfect for you."]<a href="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/baby-architect-200x300.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-493" title="baby-architect-200x300" src="http://gelottehommasblog.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/baby-architect-200x300.jpg" alt="" width="200" height="300" /></a>[/caption]

Are you a huge fan of architecture and architectural design in Seattle, but not a member of the trade? Get a glimpse and the experience of an architect’s life and outlook in a two week course of the University of Washington.

As part of their Summer Youth Programs, the University of Washington is hosting “<a title="architecture camp" href="http://www.summer-camp.uw.edu/courses/middle-school/community-architecture-environmental.asp#.TfjmrzBNxpI;facebook" target="_blank">Community Architecture: Solving Social and Environmental Issues Through Design</a>“, a two week course where middle school students can learn how architecture can shape our world, both physically and socially, by working to solve social and environmental problems with good design. During the two week event you will study basic elements of urban design and architecture, while also creating a physical and digital model just like the pros. The course will meet Monday through Friday from 9 AM until 12 PM from August 1-12 at UW Seattle. It’s $425 + $75 materials fee per participant, but you can bring your own laptop and skip the materials fee.

Are you ready to be an architect?]]></content:encoded>
